review_title: Making a difference in health care
job_title: Fund Development Manager in Calgary, AB

pros: Supporting the cause and the survivor stories

pros: Understanding and supportive Leader. They are really trying to instill a caring culture - have a ways to go, but the effort is evident. Flexibility, good work life balance, hybrid/remote work and nice office if you go in. Tons of changes since covid but they are trying their best to adapt to new ways of working in the digital world. Passionate employees about mission
cons: Lots of changes year over year. Smaller org now so fewer opportunities for advancement/development It's a NFP so of course salaries are not exactly comparable to for-profit org's but there are other things (like extra vacation and personal days) that make up for it.

pros: Lots of opportunities to learn. Lots of time off. Ok benefits.
cons: Salary is not competitive. Not much opportunity to advance

pros: Good benefits, good vacation time
cons: No leadership. Managers don’t encourage career growth. Teams are siloed and not agile. Office politics is toxic.

pros: people are nice to work with
cons: management doesn't care much for us

review_title: Limited Growth Opportunities | Challenges working in an environment of near-constant instability
pros:
Incredible PTO - with my role and pay grade, 10 weeks between vacation, personal days, Christmas closure, and sick days

Amazing benefits, particularly for mental health with up to $2,500 annually for a wide variety mental health professionals 

Incredible group of smart, talented, dedicated, kind and supportive colleagues and managers

Willingness to offer flexible, hybrid work arrangements when offices are open again
cons:
While this is slowly changing, executive team has long been out of touch with the challenges middle management and below face and this presents constant challenges

Major instability issues during my time at the Foundation - org has gone from approximately 800 employees to less than 300 over multiple periods of re-structuring during my time here

Very limited focus on supporting professional development (although this is beginning to change)

Nothing in place to facilitate succession planning and growth in the org, and people managers are often spread far too thin to have the bandwidth to meaningfully support their teams with growth and advancement 

Limited opportunities for growth - tendency not to promote from within when roles that would present a growth opportunity for someone internal, become available

job_title: Senior Assistant Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Great collaboration within team, rewarding to fundraise for an impactful mission.
cons: No path for upward mobility/promotion. A bit of a boys club feel in senior leadership.

Almost no training provided for existing and new roles. Colleagues frequently took sick leave due to burn out.

pros: Great working environment, amazing management, working for a good cause

pros:
- Friendly environment
- Helpful staff 
- Easy to grow in the company
cons: - There aren't any at this time

review_title: A safe, if boring, career choice
pros:
- Good cause with positive contributions for Canadians

- Work-life balance is solid. Most employees leave at 5:00 or earlier and the "Golden Days" in the summer are something I hope they never take away. Some departments do work from home days on an ad hoc basis as well. They're understanding of family obligations and how awful Toronto is to commute in. 

- Benefits are decent and the defined benefit contribution plan with employer matching is a bit of a unicorn nowadays.
cons:
- 1% annual salary increases. In Toronto. Are you literally joking?

- You really need to have a true interest for the not for profit sector to get enjoyment out of your job. This is true of any job, but I find it especially apparent in this industry. 

- The need to apply for your own promotion with a standard resume / cover letter process. It also takes three interviews for any associate level or higher role.

- Very little training or innovation in processes; just very little investment in the people in general. Your career will likely suffer if you stay too long as you realize your experience is less valuable outside these walls.

- Slow to evolve and technologically fractured.

- The culture here is... well, have you ever been at a really awkward party where no alcohol is served and people make superficial small talk only because they're stuck there? That's kind of what it's like. You really need to dig deep to find the interesting people. And seriously, no alcohol. Maybe a mimosa in secret or a glass of wine during the holidays.

pros: Very friendly and professional colleagues with years of experience.
cons: Lack of process-driven decision making

pros: Work life balance is awesome
cons: Constant restructuring can be demotivating

review_title: Abysmal.  Really turns you off supporting the cause - which is unfortunate.
pros:
Well known and well respected cause
Initial sense of pride to work there
Fulfilling and rewarding - working with energetic community partners, running events
cons:
Poor pay
Depressing work environment
Employee satisfaction surveys perennially low
Lots of nights and weekends 
No opportunity for advancement (as in zero - dead end job)
Unbelievably stressful
State of the economy and the impact on fundraising
Management by intimidation (is putting it lightly)
Will sour you on the cause and not for profits in general

pros:
- Your donations cover every employee's 7 weeks of annual vacation (4 weeks to start, shut down between Christmas & New Years plus 7 more summer holiday days to be taken on Mondays or Fridays in July/August), and the matching pension up to 9%. 
- HQ is centrally located on three floors at Yonge & Eglinton in Toronto, to help drive overhead costs as high as humanly possible and redirect your donations away from actual research.
- There's a new outdoor patio on the roof to jump off of when things get too stressful.
- They give you the option NOT to donate to the cause through your bi-weekly pay cheques.
cons:
- Now in competition rather than in collaboration with the Ted Rogers Centre for Heart Research
- Culture is cancerous and vapid
- Loads of turnover with next-to-no knowledge transfer
- 9 different CEOS (1 national, 8 provincial) all with different expectations/plans for how they want to run things. Yes Virginia, your donations pay for 9 CEOs salaries.
- Sr. Leadership and professional development is completely absent
- Large-scale losses in Lottery Dept drives equally large-scale layoffs across the organization
- Little-to-no strategic planning
- New brand identity/logo inspired by an emoji add-on pack, cost a crap load of $$$ and Sr. Management time, which had little-to-no discernible impact on bottom line revenues/donations
- Employee morale spends most of its time circling the toilet bowl.
- Employees spend an incredible amount of their time discussing where they're interviewing
- Salaries are incommensurate with the cost of living in the GTA. Plan to commute from New Liskeard or Lake Huron.

job_title: Community Fundraising Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: solid team environment, flexible, supportive
cons: high management turnover, office politics

pros: Good staff, vacation, benefit, values

pros: Team work and fun place to work for

review_title: PROVINCIAL CEO: Disorganized, unprofessional & extremely political.
job_title: Stroke Strategy Coordinator in Mount Pearl, NL
pros: For the most part...all other employees were very professional & agreeable to work with, having a cohesive teamwork approach.
cons: CEO was disengaged with staff; exception of one (1 of 12) & she had 6 people directly reporting to her. Extremely disorganized and unprofessional. I was hired with no operating budget?!? Who gets hired with no money for basic office requirements...photocopying, heat, mailing etc. There was major discrepancy between budget spent & allotted for my role prior to me being hired with no prior or present accountability for spending by CEO for this government funded role FOR WHICH NO ONE HAD REPLACED FOR 6 months. I had responsibility for the budget but it was overspent into my hire for F2014-15. There was no transparency about budget allocation or spend so I had to take her word that there was no money in budget eventhough there was a full years budget showing in the financial records? Was it already spent before government allocations were given for the year?!?!?

review_title: A great place to work - so many improvements over the last 8 months.
pros:
- People care about the cause and the work they do. 
- a new CEO has made changes at the Executive level making this a much better place to work. Now the leadership listen and live the values of the organization. There is much less ego and bullying from the top of the organization. 
- great benefits such as vacation and wellness days
- they have been very supportive as we all have transitioned to work from home. We have been provided with tools and the level of collaboration has improved.
cons:
- our digital sites for fundraising are out dated and hard to use. 
- Marketing team needs to collaborate more. Still an ego that think they know better but this may be a holdover from the previous leadership whose role was eliminated
- some negative employees that like to complain about everything and resisting the positive change the organization Is trying to make

review_title: Culture in MarComm left much to be desired
pros: In my time at Heart & Stroke, I was given opportunities to challenge myself, and add significant value. I took full advantage of these opportunities and learned a great deal in my role - which enabled me to ultimately find a better position elsewhere.
cons:
Unfortunately, many of those learnings were based on "what not to do in the future", rather than positive influences that I could draw from.

Navigating the politics, drama, gossip, and overall toxic environment in MarComm was exhausting on a daily basis. The word "collaboration" was a foreign concept, and the org in general was very siloed and ego-driven. Infrastructure (IT, tools, resources) was very poor and behind the times as well.

Anyone new who reported to the Digital or Creative Lead was out the door within weeks or months - I think that says it all. Until leadership changes, I wouldn't recommend working on those teams.

pros:
-This is an excellent temporary position for students who wanted to work 5:30- 9pm on weeknights. 
- Decent pay, a couple dollars over minimum wage
-Employees were very friendly people 
-this was for a great cause, trying to get volunteers to canvass door to door 
-Fast pace
-This gives you experience in targets, good for people who are interested sales
cons:
- this is for a charity, yet I feel like the supervisor is a little too pushy on making the targets, feels like they are more aiming at getting the target amount of volunteers rather than getting the right people who will actually volunteer and do the job(they probably get a lot of people who won't bother even doing the canvassing)
-Cold calling can be difficult but keeping your spirits high helps to get those volunteers!!

pros: Decent benefits package that they offer
cons: poor program and project roll out and planning. seniors leadership clueless to the needs of the front line staff. Work life balance is preached but not followed,  The exception is to check email/phone in the evening, on holidays and over winter break. Very who you know, and how quickly you can give up your values to rise to the top. Area office leaders are chosen based on how thy look on paper, good internal candidates are overlooked because of perceived lack of leadership skills and experience.  No Professional development money for staff.  over worked and under paid.

pros: I worked with a solid team who cared about the mission and was lucky to work with some great volunteers
cons: Upper management is  a complete disaster.  The only thing that matters is meeting your benchmarks (which are set without any connection to reality).  Mission is non-existent. Training is non-existent.  Meet your targets with with less and less resources is all that matters.  No innovation - their value of "learning everyday" are just words on a wall, never enters into daily life. Communication is completely one way - from the top down.  The only thing upper management wants to hear is how great their ideas are.  Reality is not welcome. Do not consider working here.

review_title: Long term employee that is happy in their job.
pros: Lots of interesting work and great people.  People come here because they want to make a difference.  There is a lot of passion; no matter what your role.  The organization is constantly changing; unification is proof of that.  We are now one large organization and with it you get growing pains. Just think how much more we can achieve.  But not everyone handles change the same way.  I've been here as long as I have because of my manager and the team I work with.
cons: Lots to do; not enough time to do it all.  We are fully funded by the donor dollar, so decisions are not made quickly and scrutinized to ensure it is the best use.  But is that really a con?

review_title: Terrible place to work since unification
pros:
Pros – Well known and well respected cause
Initial sense of pride to work there
Fulfilling and rewarding - working with energetic community partners, running events
cons:
Cons – Poor pay
Depressing work environment
Employee satisfaction surveys perennially low
Lots of nights and weekends
No opportunity for advancement (as in zero - dead end job)
Unbelievably stressful
State of the economy and the impact on fundraising
Management by intimidation (is putting it lightly)
Will sour you on the cause and not for profits in general

Advice to Senior Management – Unbelievably high turnover - through termination, not voluntarily.

Absolutely no upper management leadership, the place is run by monkeys.
As with all not for profits the salary is beyond meager, I'm pretty sure there are kids in China making more money than full time permanent employees at the H&S while upper management make six figures.

Lots of unpaid nights and weekends - you are shamed at the thought of taking your time back.

pros: Great people (co-workers and volunteers).  A lot of disconnect between departments, but friendly, helpful staff.  A sense of pride can be had in the work, if you remember it helps aid research for heart and stroke events.
cons: Lack of support.  While co-workers try or want to help, their management tells them not to.  Lack of direction from management, who just seem to be there to get a paycheque.  Lack of innovation in fundraising.

pros:
-Very good vacation package : 3-4 weeks starting, 10 personal days, closed during Christmas holidays
-People are passionate about cause, although management seems to take advantage of that and imagine people will just devote their life to the foundation just out of passion
-flexible hours and flexibility to work from home
cons:
I would not recommend anyone working there
-Toxic environment, managers and up are bullies and use the genuine kindness of less senior employees to manipulate them
- Teams work in silos and collaboration between employees is not encouraged, feels like everything you do has to be a secret you cannot share with others 
- supposedly risk management but in reality it’s micromanagement. - - The foundation cares more about its image than its employees. It will do anything to preserve its positive image in the public, even though if inside everything is tearing down
- no clear direction. How many more restructuring do we need before they realize that it’s upper management that needs to go. With each re structuring, the bullies stay and the nice honest people with integrity are let go
- lack of transparency and ethics
- just goes by rules and procedures instead of using common sense
- spend most time working on developing procedures and rules that will only serve once than actually implementing things right
- the foundation says it promotes diversity, but most senior roles are occupied by Caucasian in a disproportionate manner
- no opportunity for growth... honestly Lynda.com... and that’s it.
- fools people into thinking they are saving lives when everything they want in the end is to obtain more funding so that they can keep their jobs
- incompetent people in senior roles. Bullies managing people.
I could go on and on but basically my message is to stay away from the organization. I don’t even want to support it as a charity knowing how things work internally.

pros: People working there are with open heart to teach you whatever you want learn as a member of the team. They are efficient and have a clear mind. They are nice to clients and their employees, which I mean real nice. Your can share your abilities and devote yourself there and also can improve your skills as you wish because they would love to see you success.
cons: It couldn't be a CON actually. They will sing and dance on Friday, which will make you pretty enjoy working on friday.

review_title: Good extras, low pay and lack of direction
pros:
Lots of vacation time, plus golden days in summer (6 bonus days off to make long weekends), plus time between Christmas and New Years paid.
Really friendly staff and helpful colleagues.
Somewhat flexible on start/end times to your day.
cons: Salary low, but to be expected with a non-profit. Manager was often unaware of my workload and I was always looking for more to do. Teams don't communicate much on work so there are always things missed between fundraising teams and events.

pros: Working for a good cause, gaining experience, good location, pension benefits, giving back to the community, flexible schedule, ability to work from home
cons: salary, no career opportunities, high workload, senior management, lack of recognition, high staff tunover, lack of communication, lack of feedback, had 4 bosses in 4 years, alot of favoritism
